lab5TicTacToe

Class TicTacToe

  • java.lang.Object
    • lab5TicTacToe.TicTacToe

  • public class TicTacToe
extends java.lang.Object
    This class will hold all the methods for a console based tic tac toe game, including a game loop
    Author:
    Ylva

    • Field Summary

      Fields 
      Modifier and Type Field and Description
      private char[][] game
      This character array will hold the game field, it will be the size of the game A value can be either 'A'(empty) 'O'(player sign) or 'X'(other player sign)
      private int gameSize
      The size of the board We could use a byte type to save memory here, and if we would do that we could make the moveCount a short.
      private int moveCount
      This integer counts the amount of moves, it is started at 0, every even move is a move made by the starting player (where 0 is said to be even)
      private char starter
      This char is either X or O depending on which user starts

    • Constructor Summary

      Constructors 
      Constructor and Description
      TicTacToe()
      Default constructor, Sets the size of the game to 4 The starting player to X And initializes the game array as being filled with 'A'
      TicTacToe(byte size)
      Constructor that initializes the board on a specific size Sets the starting player to X
      TicTacToe(char start)
      Constructor that specifies which user starts Sets the board size to 4
      TicTacToe(int size, char start)
      Constructor that can set the starting user and the board size

    • Method Summary

      Methods 
      Modifier and Type Method and Description
      private boolean columnWin(int column)
      Will win if the player who's turn it is has a winning condition in the specified column
      private boolean draw()
      Will return a true if the game has gone into a draw
      private void emptyGame()
      I ran into problems with the way I initialized the game array, Since the array size is usually really small we can just use a simple loop iteration to make the array hold values of 'A'
      private boolean endGame()
      This method will check if the game has ended
      private boolean fullField()
      Will return true if the field is full
      char GetWinner()
      Retrieves the winner, should only be run when endGame() is true
      private boolean leftDiagonalWin()
      Will win if the player who's turn it is has a winning condition in diagonal from the top left to the bottom right
      private boolean rightDiagonalWin()
      Will win if the player who's turn it is has a winning condition in diagonal from the bottom left to the top right
      private boolean rowWin(int row)
      Will win if the player who's turn it is has a winning condition in the specified row
      char turn()
      returns who's turn it is

      • Methods inherited from class java.lang.Object

        clone, equals, finalize, getClass, hashCode, notify, notifyAll, toString, wait, wait, wait

    • Field Detail

      • game

        private char[][] game
        This character array will hold the game field, it will be the size of the game A value can be either 'A'(empty) 'O'(player sign) or 'X'(other player sign)

      • moveCount

        private int moveCount
        This integer counts the amount of moves, it is started at 0, every even move is a move made by the starting player (where 0 is said to be even)

      • starter

        private char starter
        This char is either X or O depending on which user starts

      • gameSize

        private int gameSize
        The size of the board We could use a byte type to save memory here, and if we would do that we could make the moveCount a short. However due to the way java works on 32 bit systems (And most systems have either a 32 or 64 bit architecture) it will allocate the room for an int type anyway. This means the Java Virtual Machine has to do additional checks in order to do arithmetic on short and byte types. This actually results in a penalty in terms of actual computing time. More on this subject can be found at http://stackoverflow.com/questions/14531235/in-java-is-it-more-efficient-to-use-byte-or-short-instead-of-int-and-float-inst

    • Constructor Detail

      • TicTacToe

        public TicTacToe()
        Default constructor, Sets the size of the game to 4 The starting player to X And initializes the game array as being filled with 'A'

      • TicTacToe

        public TicTacToe(byte size)
        Constructor that initializes the board on a specific size Sets the starting player to X
        Parameters:
        size - the size the board should have

      • TicTacToe

        public TicTacToe(char start)
        Constructor that specifies which user starts Sets the board size to 4
        Parameters:
        start - has to be either 'X' or 'O'

      • TicTacToe

        public TicTacToe(int size,
         char start)
        Constructor that can set the starting user and the board size
        Parameters:
        size - the board size, has to be higher then 2
        start - the starting char, has to be either 'X' or 'O'

      • turn

        public char turn()
        returns who's turn it is
        Returns:
        the char of the player who's turn it is

      • endGame

        private boolean endGame()
        This method will check if the game has ended
        Returns:
        true if the game has ended

      • draw

        private boolean draw()
        Will return a true if the game has gone into a draw
        Returns:
        true if the game is a draw

      • fullField

        private boolean fullField()
        Will return true if the field is full
        Returns:
        true if all the places on the field have something in them

      • columnWin

        private boolean columnWin(int column)
        Will win if the player who's turn it is has a winning condition in the specified column
        Parameters:
        column - the column to check
        Returns:
        true if the current player has won with this column

      • rowWin

        private boolean rowWin(int row)
        Will win if the player who's turn it is has a winning condition in the specified row
        Parameters:
        row - the row to check
        Returns:
        true if the current player has won with this row

      • leftDiagonalWin

        private boolean leftDiagonalWin()
        Will win if the player who's turn it is has a winning condition in diagonal from the top left to the bottom right
        Returns:
        true if the current player has won with this diagonal

      • rightDiagonalWin

        private boolean rightDiagonalWin()
        Will win if the player who's turn it is has a winning condition in diagonal from the bottom left to the top right
        Returns:
        true if the current player has won with this diagonal

      • GetWinner

        public char GetWinner()
        Retrieves the winner, should only be run when endGame() is true
        Returns:
        an 'A' if draw, otherwise an 'X' or 'O'

      • emptyGame

        private void emptyGame()
        I ran into problems with the way I initialized the game array, Since the array size is usually really small we can just use a simple loop iteration to make the array hold values of 'A'
